name: lane
content:
lane

noun
 
 
/leɪn/
 
/leɪn/
Idioms
jump to other results
  1. enlarge image
     
    a narrow road in the country
    • winding country lanes
    • We drove along a muddy lane to reach the farmhouse.
    see also memory lane
    Extra Examples
    • The lane runs past the lake.
    • We cycled for miles along winding country lanes.
    • We drove down winding country lanes on the journey to York.
    • the lane leading to the village
    • A little lane winds down to the coast.
    • Cattle were being led along the lane.
    • I turned into the lane where I lived.
    • Outside the village we turned into a leafy lane leading to a farm.
    • The lane petered out in a muddy track.
    • They drove along the winding lanes.
    • They live in a cottage in Church Lane.
    • They used to go and pick blackberries along the lanes.
    • We left the car at the end of the lane.
    • We walked down the quiet country lane towards the riverbank.
    Topics Transport by car or lorryb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • narrow
    • little
    • small
    • …
    verb + lane
    • turn down
    • turn into
    lane + verb
    • go
    • lead
    • run
    • …
    preposition
    • along a/​the lane
    • down a/​the lane
    • in a/​the lane
    • …
    See full entry
  2.  
    (often in place names) a city street
    • Park Lane
    • The quickest way is through the back lanes behind the bus station.
    Extra Examples
    • Lighting is poor in the back lanes of the city.
    • There is plenty to explore in the narrow winding lanes behind the cathedral.
    • The address is 53 Chancery Lane.
    Topics Transport by car or lorryb2
  3.  
    a section of a wide road, that is marked by painted white lines, to keep lines of traffic separate
    • the inside/middle lane
    • the northbound/southbound lane
    • to change lanes
    • She signalled and pulled over into the slow lane.
    • a four-lane highway
    see also bicycle lane, bike lane, breakdown lane, bus lane, cycle lane, fast lane, HOV lane, outside lane, passing lane, slow lane
    Wordfinder
    • bypass
    • carriageway
    • diversion
    • hard shoulder
    • lane
    • lay-by
    • motorway
    • road
    • roundabout
    • signpost
    Extra Examples
    • Commuters can expect lane closures for a while longer.
    • Get in lane early when approaching a junction.
    • I hate changing lanes on the motorway.
    • I hate changing lanes when the traffic is heavy.
    • Lane closures are causing hold-ups on the M6 near junction 2.
    • The bus was crawling along in the slow lane.
    Topics Transport by car or lorryb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • fast
    • slow
    • left
    • …
    verb + lane
    • change
    • get in
    • switch
    • …
    lane + noun
    • closures
    • restrictions
    preposition
    • in (the) lane
    See full entry
  4. enlarge image
     
    a narrow marked section of a track or a swimming pool that is used by one person, for example when taking part in a race
    • The Australian in lane four is coming up fast from behind.
    • Obi, the record holder, is in lane 3.
    Topics Sports: water sportsc1, Sports: other sportsc1
  5.  
    a route used by ships or aircraft on regular journeys
    • one of the world’s busiest shipping/sea lanes
    see also air lane, sea lane
  6. enlarge image
    (in tenpin bowling) a narrow section of floor along which the ball is bowled
    • a 20-lane bowling alley
    7. Word OriginOld English, related to Dutch laan; of unknown ultimate origin.
Idioms
in the fast lane
  1. where things are most exciting and where a lot is happening
    • He had a good job, plenty of money and he was enjoying life in the fast lane.
See lane in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: lane

name: air lane
content:
air lane

noun
 
/ˈeə leɪn/
 
/ˈer leɪn/
jump to other results
  1. a route regularly used by aircraftTopics Transport by airc2
See air lane in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: bus lane
content:
bus lane

noun
 
/ˈbʌs leɪn/
 
/ˈbʌs leɪn/
jump to other results
  1. a part of a road that only buses are allowed to useTopics Transport by car or lorryb2, Transport by bus and trainb2
See bus lane in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: bus lane

name: Gin Lane
content:
Gin Lane

 
/ˌdʒɪn ˈleɪn/
 
/ˌdʒɪn ˈleɪn/
jump to other results
  1. a drawing (1751) by William Hogarth. It is a shocking picture of people in a London street who are too drunk to care about their homes or families. gin, a strong alcoholic drink, was very popular at the time because of its low price, and many people in London were drinking too much of it.
Check pronunciation: Gin Lane

name: HOV lane
content:
HOV lane

noun
 
/ˌeɪtʃ əʊ ˈviː leɪn/
 
/ˌeɪtʃ əʊ ˈviː leɪn/
 (especially North American English)
jump to other results
  1. high-occupancy vehicle lane
    (a part of the road that may only be used by vehicles that are carrying two or more people)
    • The route has one HOV lane in each direction.
    • The police pulled over a lone driver using the HOV lane.
    Topics Transport by car or lorryc2
See HOV lane in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: HOV lane

name: sea lane
content:
sea lane

noun
 
/ˈsiː leɪn/
 
/ˈsiː leɪn/
jump to other results
  1. an official route at sea that is regularly used by shipsTopics Transport by waterc2
See sea lane in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: sea lane

name: bike lane
content:
bike lane

noun
 
/ˈbaɪk leɪn/
 
/ˈbaɪk leɪn/
 (North American English, informal)
(North American English also bicycle lane, British English cycle lane)
jump to other results
  1. a part of a road that only bicycles are allowed to useTopics Transport by car or lorryb2
See bike lane in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: bike lane

name: fast lane
content:
fast lane

noun
 
/ˈfɑːst leɪn/
 
/ˈfæst leɪn/
 [singular]Idioms
jump to other results
  1. the part of a major road such as a motorway or interstate where vehicles drive fastestTopics Transport by car or lorryb2
Idioms
in the fast lane
  1. where things are most exciting and where a lot is happening
    • He had a good job, plenty of money and he was enjoying life in the fast lane.
See fast lane in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: fast lane

name: Park Lane
content:
Park Lane

 
/ˌpɑːk ˈleɪn/
 
/ˌpɑːrk ˈleɪn/
jump to other results
  1. a street in the centre of London, along the eastern side of Hyde Park, near Mayfair. It is known for its very expensive houses and hotels, including the Dorchester.
Check pronunciation: Park Lane

name: slow lane
content:
slow lane

noun
 
/ˈsləʊ leɪn/
 
/ˈsləʊ leɪn/
 [singular]Idioms
jump to other results
  1. the part of a major road such as a motorway or interstate where vehicles drive slowestTopics Transport by car or lorryb2
Idioms
in the slow lane
  1. not making progress as fast as other people, countries, companies, etc.
See slow lane in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: slow lane

name: cycle lane

cycle lane

noun
 
/ˈsaɪkl leɪn/
 
/ˈsaɪkl leɪn/
 (British English)
(North American English bicycle lane, informal bike lane)
jump to other results
  1. enlarge image
    a part of a road that only bicycles are allowed to use
    • Cars are not allowed in the cycle lanes.
    Topics Transport by car or lorryb2
Check pronunciation: cycle lane

name: Drury Lane
content:
Drury Lane

 
/ˌdrʊəri ˈleɪn/
 
/ˌdrʊri ˈleɪn/
jump to other results
  1. a street in central London, near Covent Garden, which contains the Theatre Royal

/ˌləʊɪs ˈleɪn/

jump to other results
  1. Superman

name: memory lane
content:
memory lane

noun
 
/ˌmeməri ˈleɪn/
 
/ˌmeməri ˈleɪn/
Idioms
jump to other results
Idioms
a trip/walk down memory lane
  1. time that you spend thinking about and remembering the past or going to a place again in order to remind yourself of past experiences
    • Visiting my old school was a real trip down memory lane.
See memory lane in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: memory lane

name: express lane
content:
express lane

noun
 
/ɪkˈspres leɪn/
 
/ɪkˈspres leɪn/
 (especially North American English)
jump to other results
  1. part of a road on which certain vehicles can travel faster because there is less trafficTopics Transport by car or lorryc1
  2. a place in a shop where customers can pay without having to wait for a long time
    • Customers with ten items or less can use the express lane.
    compare checkout (1), till (2)
See express lane in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: express lane

name: outside lane
content:
outside lane

noun
 
/ˌaʊtsaɪd ˈleɪn/
 
/ˌaʊtsaɪd ˈleɪn/
 (British English)
(North American English passing lane)
jump to other results
  1. the part of a major road such as a motorway or interstate nearest the middle of the road, where vehicles drive fastest and can go past vehicles aheadTopics Transport by car or lorryb2
Check pronunciation: outside lane

name: passing lane
content:
passing lane

noun
 
/ˈpɑːsɪŋ leɪn/
 
/ˈpæsɪŋ leɪn/
 (North American English)
(British English outside lane)
jump to other results
  1. the part of a major road such as a motorway or interstate nearest the middle of the road, where vehicles drive fastest and can go past vehicles aheadTopics Transport by car or lorryc1
See passing lane in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: passing lane

name: breakdown lane
content:
breakdown lane

noun
 
/ˈbreɪkdaʊn leɪn/
 
/ˈbreɪkdaʊn leɪn/
 (US English)
(British English hard shoulder)
jump to other results
  1. a narrow piece of ground with a hard surface next to a major road such as a motorway or interstate where vehicles can stop in an emergencyTopics Transport by car or lorryc1
Check pronunciation: breakdown lane

name: Petticoat Lane
content:
Petticoat Lane

 
/ˌpetɪkəʊt ˈleɪn/
 
/ˌpetɪkəʊt ˈleɪn/
jump to other results
  1. a street in the East End of London, where a famous market takes place every Sunday, selling a wide variety of goods. The name of the street was changed to Middlesex Street in the 19th century, but people still refer to the market as Petticoat Lane.
Check pronunciation: Petticoat Lane

name: White Hart Lane
content:
White Hart Lane

 
/ˌwaɪt hɑːt ˈleɪn/
 
/ˌwaɪt hɑːrt ˈleɪn/
jump to other results
  1. a well-known football ground in north London. It is the home of Tottenham Hotspur football club.
Check pronunciation: White Hart Lane
